"Crashing into a Fantasy World," a Story by a Reddit user, was published in October 2021. I wrote this story as a response to the prompt "An alien swarm species crashes down on a fantasy world." 
Here is the story:

The sky was a deep, fiery red, and the air was thick with the smell of smoke and ash. I lay on my back, my eyes fixed on the burning trees above me. The world around me was on fire, and I was trapped in the middle of it. The forest was ablaze, the flames licking at the trees like tongues of fire. I could hear the sound of crackling and the occasional thud as a tree fell. I tried to move, but my body was heavy, weighed down by some unseen force.

I tried to stand, but my legs wouldn’t respond. I was trapped, unable to move or escape the burning world around me. I lay there, my eyes fixed on the flames, my mind racing with thoughts of survival. I had to find a way out of this place, before it was too late.

As I lay there, I heard a strange noise, a rustling in the bushes nearby. I turned my head, trying to see what was making the noise. A figure emerged from the smoke, a tall, gaunt creature with long, spindly limbs. Its skin was deathly pale, and its eyes were black as coal. It moved with a strange, unnatural gait, as if it was being pulled along by some unseen force.

The creature moved closer, its eyes fixed on me. I tried to move, but my body was still trapped, unable to respond. The creature leaned over me, its face twisted in a cruel smile. I tried to scream, but my voice was stuck in my throat. The creature reached out, its long fingers wrapping around my wrist. I felt a jolt of pain, and my body was released from its trance-like state.

I sat up, looking around at the burning world around me. The creature stood over me, its eyes fixed on me. I looked at it, trying to understand what it was. It was alien, a creature from another world. I had heard of such creatures, but I had never seen one before. It was a member of the swarm, a collective of creatures that had been brought to this world from a distant planet.

The creature spoke to me, its voice like a series of clicks and chirps. I didn’t understand what it was saying, but I knew that it was trying to communicate with me. I looked at it, trying to understand its words. It was a member of the swarm, a creature that had been brought to this world to study the inhabitants. It was a peaceful creature, but it was also fiercely intelligent.

I'd been a slave for so long, I'd almost forgotten I was a person.

My memories of life before are fragmented and unclear. I'd been a child when they'd taken me, probably no more than 5 or 6 years old. I'd been given to the villain as a child, and I'd grown up being their plaything, their experimental subject, their slave.

I'd lost count of how many years I'd been a slave. I'd been a slave for so long, I'd almost forgotten I was a person.

My master's lair was a strange place. It was a maze of corridors and rooms, with strange contraptions and machines lining the walls. My master would experiment on me, using those contraptions and machines to try and break my spirit. But I never broke. I never cracked. I never showed any signs of weakness.

My master was a master of the mind. He was a master of the art of torture, and he knew exactly what he was doing. He'd whisper evil thoughts into my mind, trying to break my spirit. But I never broke. I never cracked. I never showed any signs of weakness.

I'd been a slave for so long, I'd almost forgotten I was a person.

One day, my master asked me a question. "How do you not go insane from the constant evil thoughts I whisper into your mind?" he asked. I was taken aback by the question. I didn't know how to explain it. "Because it's normal," I said. "Because it's the way I've always been." I shrugged. "I'm a slave, my mind is their plaything. They can do whatever they want with it. I don't have any control over my mind. They control my mind."

My master nodded. "Ah, yes. I forgot that you're a slave. That you don't have any control over your mind. You're just a tool, a plaything. A slave is nothing more than a tool, a plaything."

I nodded. "Yes. That's right."

"Princess of the Tower" is a fantasy story about a princess who is imprisoned in an abandoned tower and spends years slowly learning the art of wizardry. This story was written by u/kikukawai on the website Reddit.

Princess Sophia had been imprisoned in the abandoned tower for five years. She had been captured by her enemies, the dark sorcerer, Lord Cygnus and his loyal knight, Sir Valoric. Sophia had been the object of Lord Cygnus' affections, and he had stolen her away from her father's kingdom. The tower was once home to a great wizard, who had spent his life studying the arcane arts.

Over the years, Sophia had tried to escape, but it had been futile. The tower was guarded by powerful magic spells, and any attempt to leave would be met with death. However, Sophia had found a way to keep herself occupied. She had discovered the wizard's library, where she had spent countless hours studying the arcane lore left behind. She had learned how to read, write, and cast simple spells.

Sophia had learned that she was not just any princess. She was a princess of the wizarding bloodline. Her ancestors had been great wizards, and they had passed down their knowledge to her. Sophia had always felt a connection to the wizarding world, but she had never realized just how much magic ran through her veins.

As Sophia delved deeper into her studies, she began to realize just how much she had missed. She had been imprisoned for five years, and she had never seen the outside world. She had only read about it in the books. She had always wondered what it would be like to walk outside, to feel the sun on her face, and to breathe fresh air.

One day, Sophia was ready. She had spent five years studying the arcane lore, and she had learned enough to be able to escape. She had cast simple spells, learned how to read the wizard's ancient language, and had discovered the secrets of the tower's magic. She was ready to leave.

I-I wanted to make a good impression,” the young adventurer said, trying to avoid eye contact. He knew that was a terrible answer, and that the Guild Leader was going to have a lot of questions.

The young adventurer had been a member of the Guild of Heroes for about a month. He had heard of the legend of the Dragon King, and he had heard of the legend of the Northern Bandit Tribes. He had heard that they were both powerful and feared.
And so, he decided to go on a quest to defeat the Dragon King and wipe out the Northern Bandit Tribes.
But there was one more thing that he had to do. He had to rescue six cats from trees.
He had seen the cats in a tree in the park. They were cats. They were small. They were cute. And they were in a tree.
And so, he decided to climb the tree and rescue the cats. He had heard that the cats were cute and would be fun to play with.
He climbed the tree and reached the top. He saw the cats sitting in the branches. He reached out and picked them up. And he put them in his bag.

I looked down at my clothes, making sure I was decent before heading out to search for food. I always made sure to dress appropriately, especially when I was going out in public. You'd be surprised how many humans were offended by the sight of a vampire in their "home town".
I slipped on my coat and headed out into the night. I wasn't really sure what I was looking for, but I had a feeling that I'd know it when I saw it. I'd been in this town for a while now, and I'd learned to recognize the different types of food.
I started walking down the sidewalk, my eyes scanning the buildings for any sign of what I was looking for. The first thing I noticed was a sign that read "Burgers, Sandwiches, Salads..." Ah, a restaurant! But not just any restaurant, a 24 hour diner. I loved those places.
I pushed open the door and stepped inside. The bell above the door rang out, and the patrons looked up at me. I just smiled and nodded, trying to blend in. I spotted a booth in the back that looked like it was available, and I made my way over to it.
As I sat down, I noticed a woman sitting in the booth across from me. She looked like she was in her mid-twenties, with long brown hair and a small nose ring. She was typing away on her phone, and she looked up at me as I sat down.

A loud, piercing sound came from the direction of the landing strip. I saw a bunch of armed space pirates, with some big, nasty-looking ships, landing near the colony.

"Looks like they're here to plunder our supplies," I said to my wife, Elara. "Again."

"Can you believe it?" Elara said, shaking her head. "We thought we were safe out here."

"I know," I said, sighing. "I've been designing weapons for the government for years. I thought I'd made a difference, but I guess not."

I watched as the pirates began to unload their cargo. They were armed to the teeth, and it looked like they had been raiding the same place before. I recognized some of the stuff they were stealing. "Looks like they took our supplies last time," I said to Elara.

"I know," she said, shaking her head. "But we need that stuff to survive."

I walked over to the landing strip, my wife by my side. "Hey, pirates!" I yelled. "What do you want?"

One of the pirates, a tall, muscular man with a scar across his cheek, walked over to me. "We want your supplies," he said, sneering at me. "You're just a bunch of peaceful colonists. You don't need all this stuff."

"We need it to survive," I said. "We have families to feed."

The pirate sneered at me again. "We'll just take what we need," he said. "You can always make more supplies."

I knew that was a lie. The pirates had been coming here for months, taking everything we needed to survive. And now, they were stealing our garden robot, which was the last thing we needed to make food.

I knew I had to act fast. "I'll give you a deal," I said to the pirate. "You can have all our supplies, but you have to give us back our garden robot."

The pirate laughed. "You think we'd ever give you back your precious robot? You're just a bunch of colonists. We're space pirates. We don't care about your little robot."

I knew I had to think fast. "Fine," I said. "Then I'll give you a challenge. If you can defeat me in a duel, you can keep all our supplies."

The pirate laughed again. "You think you can defeat me? I'm a space pirate. I've been in more battles than you've had hot meals."

I knew I had to be careful. But I also knew I had to act fast. "Fine," I said. "But if I win, you have to give us back our garden robot."

The pirate nodded. "Okay. But if I win, you have to give us all your supplies."

I nodded. "Okay."

The pirate grinned at me. "Let's go!"

I knew I had to be careful. The pirate was big and muscular, and he had a scar across his cheek. But I also knew I had to act fast. I walked over to the pirate and nodded. "Let's go!"

The pirate charged at me, his fist flying towards my face. I dodged it easily and punched him in the stomach. He doubled over, gasping for breath.

I knew I had to be quick. I punched him again and again, until he fell to the ground, defeated.

The pirate's men ran away, abandoning their cargo. I walked over to the cargo and saw that they had stolen all our supplies. But I also saw that they had left behind our garden robot.

I smiled. "I guess I won," I said to Elara.

"Yes," she said, smiling at me. "You did."

**Sherlock Holmes: The Return of the Watson**

Sherlock Holmes had always been an island unto himself. Self-sufficient, aloof, with a mind that raced like a machine, he had a way of making everyone feel like they were just a tiny cog in his grand machine. But there was one person, one person in the entire world, who could make him feel like he wasn't quite so alone. And that person was Dr. John Watson.

Years ago, when Watson had first come to live with Holmes, the young doctor had been so full of life, so eager to explore the world and all its secrets. And Holmes, for all his cold exterior, had been drawn to the warmth and kindness of Watson's heart. They had made a good team, Watson and Holmes, the doctor's practicality complementing the detective's brilliance, and together they had solved case after case, their names becoming synonymous with detection.

But when the war came, Watson had gone off to fight, leaving Holmes behind, alone and desolate. Holmes had been like a ship without a rudder, adrift in a sea of uncertainty, his mind consumed by the fear of losing the one person who truly mattered to him.

And now, years later, Watson was coming home.

Sherlock Holmes sat in the garden, staring out at the sunlight that filtered through the trees, feeling a sense of unease in his chest. What would Watson be like when he arrived? Would he still be the same man, the same friend? Or would he be different, changed by the war and all its horrors?

As he pondered these questions, a car pulled up the drive, and Watson got out, looking pale and worn, but with a spark of life in his eyes that made Holmes's heart leap with joy. He leapt up, the chair scraping against the grass, and ran to meet his friend, his arms open wide in welcome.

"Watson!" he exclaimed, hugging him tightly. "My dear Watson! Welcome home!"

Watson smiled, his eyes shining with happiness, and hugged Holmes back. "Holmes," he said, his voice trembling with emotion. "I'm home. I'm finally home."

Holmes pushed him away, looking him up and down. "You look like you could use a good meal and a warm bath," he said, his eyes sparkling with concern. "I'll get the kettle on and the water running. You can have a cup of tea, and I'll make sure you're comfortable."

Watson nodded, his eyes dropping as he looked at the ground. "I'm tired, Holmes," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "I'm so tired."

Holmes nodded, his face softening with compassion. "I know," he said, his voice gentle. "You've been through a lot, Watson. I'll get the tea and the bath, and we'll get you all settled in. Then we can talk."

Watson nodded, his eyes rising to meet Holmes's. "I'd like that," he said, his voice a little stronger now.

Holmes nodded, and turned to go inside. "I'll get the tea and the bath," he said, his back to Watson. "Just stay right where you are, and I'll be back in a minute."

Watson nodded, his eyes fixed on Holmes's back as he disappeared into the house. He took a deep breath, feeling a sense of peace wash over him. He was home, and Holmes was here to welcome him.

"Tea and bath ready," he said, his voice low and soothing. "Let's get you all settled in, and then we can talk."

Holmes nodded, and stood up, offering his hand to help Watson to his feet. "Come on," he said, his voice gentle. "Let's get you all settled in."

Watson took Holmes's hand, and let him pull him to his feet. As they walked towards the house, Holmes's arm around his shoulders, Watson felt a sense of peace wash over him. He was home, and Holmes was here to welcome him.

The sun was setting over Baker Street when I walked into our lodgings, the door creaking open to reveal the familiar sight of Sherlock Holmes pacing around the room, lost in thought. It had been years since we’d been reunited, and we’d settled back into our old routines with ease. But I knew that beneath his usual façade, he was still the same man he’d always been – brilliant, unpredictable, and deeply troubled.

As I hung my hat on the peg and removed my coat, he turned to me, his eyes narrowing as he studied me. I felt a shiver run down my spine, but I knew him well enough to know that he was simply trying to determine how much rest I’d had and how long it had been since I’d last eaten.

“Watson, my dear fellow,” he said, his voice dripping with the usual sarcasm, “I trust you’re feeling refreshed after your long journey. I must admit, I was a bit worried about you – the streets can be treacherous, you know.”

I smiled, knowing that he was trying to ease me into the conversation he was going to have with me. “I’m feeling fine, Holmes,” I said, taking a seat on the couch beside him. “And I’m grateful for your concern. But I think you have something on your mind. What is it?”

He leaned back in his chair, his eyes fixed on some point in the distance. “I was wondering,” he said finally, “if you might be willing to do something for me.”

I felt a surge of excitement mixed with trepidation. There was always something that he wanted me to do, some errand or favor that he needed me to perform. And usually, it was something that was going to get me into trouble. “What is it, Holmes?” I asked, trying to keep my voice neutral.

He sighed, his shoulders slumping in defeat. “I know that I’ve been gone for a long time,” he said, “and I know that people have been talking about me. They think I’m dead, don’t they?”

I nodded, feeling a pang of sadness. It was true – the entire city had believed that he was dead, and had even gone so far as to write him off as a myth. And I knew that he was deeply troubled by this, that he felt like he’d lost his sense of purpose and identity.

“Well, you’re not dead,” I said, trying to reassure him. “You’re very much alive, and you’re still the same man you’ve always been.”

Sherlock Holmes, the famous detective, sat at his desk, staring at the wall. It was a bit of a monotony for him, always being asked the same questions. He loved the detective work, but sometimes he just felt like he was stuck in a rut.

Just then, the doorbell rang. It was Dr. John Watson, his trusty sidekick and friend. "Hey, Sherlock, I've got a bit of a problem," Watson said, as he walked into the room.

"What kind of problem?" Sherlock asked, as he looked up from his book.

"Well, I just got a letter from a client who says they have a problem with a blackmailer. They want me to help them solve it."

Sherlock's eyes lit up. "A blackmailer, you say? That sounds like a challenge. Let's go!"

They got into a cab and headed to the client's office. When they arrived, they met with the client, a young woman who was crying. "Please, you have to help me," she said, as Sherlock listened to her story.

Sherlock nodded. "Don't worry, I'll help you. We'll catch this blackmailer and make them pay."

As they left the office, Watson turned to Sherlock. "You know, I think I've been thinking about this case too much. It's been bothering me."

Sherlock looked at him. "What do you mean?"

"Well, I just can't seem to get it out of my head. I keep thinking about the blackmailer and how they must have felt, to have been in such a situation."

Sherlock nodded. "I understand. It's a tough case, but we'll get it solved."

They arrived at the client's house and started to investigate. They found a small note on the table that said, "Meet me at the old windmill at midnight." Sherlock's eyes lit up. "This is it, Watson. We've got our blackmailer!"

But just as they were about to leave, a figure emerged from the shadows. It was a young man, and he was holding a gun.

"I'm afraid you're not going anywhere, Sherlock," he said, as he aimed the gun at them.

Sherlock's eyes narrowed. "You're the blackmailer, aren't you?"

The young man nodded. "Yes, I am. And I'm going to make you pay for all the trouble you've caused me."

Sherlock's eyes widened. "You're going to kill us?"

The young man nodded again. "Yes, I am. And I'm going to enjoy it."

Sherlock's eyes narrowed again. "I don't think so," he said, as he lunged at the young man.

The young man was caught off guard, and he fell to the ground. Sherlock stood over him, holding the gun.

"It's over," he said, as he looked at the young man.

But just as they were about to leave, Mycroft Holmes arrived. "Sherlock, I've been looking for you," he said, as he walked into the room.

Sherlock looked at him. "What do you want, Mycroft?"

"I want you to take a vacation," he said, as he looked at Sherlock.

"A vacation?" Sherlock repeated. "What do you mean?"

"I mean, you need to take a break," Mycroft said, as he looked at Sherlock.

Sherlock raised an eyebrow. "A break?"

"Yes, a break," Mycroft said, as he nodded.

Sherlock looked at Watson. "What do you think?"

Watson shrugged. "I think it's a good idea. You've been working too hard."

Sherlock nodded. "Okay, I'll take a break."

But as they left the house, Sherlock couldn't help but wonder if Mycroft's concern was genuine or if there was something more sinister afoot.

As they walked to the train station, Sherlock's mind was racing. He couldn't shake the feeling that something was off.

"What's wrong, Sherlock?" Watson asked, as he looked at him.

"Nothing," Sherlock said, as he shook his head.

pred_story:
In the dim, warm light of the Labyrinth's corridors, Nico trudged along, his eyes scanning the floor for any sign of the next marker. His hand closed over the small pouch of coins in his belt and his gaze darted to his backpack, slung over his shoulder. He was out of snacks.

As he turned a corner, a small boy appeared before him, his bright blue eyes sparkling with mischief. Nico's hand went to the short sword at his belt, but something about the boy's smile stayed his hand.

“Hey, mister,” the boy said, his voice high and cheerful. “My name is Timmy. What's yours?”

Nico hesitated for a moment before shaking his head. “I don't think we have time for names.”

Timmy's face fell, but he bounced up and down on his toes. “Oh, come on! I love making new friends! Don't you want to be friends with me? I'm from the future. I know all the best routes.”

Nico raised an eyebrow. “The future? What do you mean?”

Timmy grinned. “You know, the future! After you get out of the Labyrinth. Don't you want to know what happens next?”
Nico felt a shiver run down his spine. He had never heard of anyone escaping the Labyrinth, let alone going on to live a life after it.
“I'm not sure I'm ready to hear what happens next,” he said slowly. “Maybe some other time. I have to keep moving.”
Timmy's face fell, but he nodded and skipped off down the corridor.
Nico watched him go, feeling a shiver run down his spine. What had that boy been saying? About the future? Nico didn't even know if the Labyrinth had a future, or if anyone who made it through would live to tell the tale.

As he walked, Nico's mind kept turning over Timmy's words. What did it mean to be from the future? And why had the boy said he was his future boyfriend? Nico shook his head, chuckling to himself. That was just ridiculous. He couldn't be in a relationship. He was on his own, after all.

But as he walked, he couldn't shake the feeling that there was something more to it. Something more to Timmy's words than just a silly game.

As he turned a corner, he caught sight of a boy standing in the doorway of a room ahead. The boy was tall, with dark hair and a lean, athletic build. Nico's heart caught in his throat and he felt a flush rise to his cheeks.
“Who are you?” Nico asked, his voice a little higher than he would have liked.
The boy turned and smiled at him, and Nico felt his heart skip a beat.
“I'm Max,” the boy said, his voice low and smooth. “I'm from the future too.”
Nico's eyes widened. “The future?” he repeated, feeling a little awestruck.
Max nodded. “Yeah. Me too. Timmy and I go to school together.”
Nico's mind reeled as he tried to wrap his head around it all. The future? School? It was all too much to take in.
But as he looked at Max, he felt a shiver run down his spine. Maybe it wasn't so bad after all.
“Let's go talk to Timmy,” Max said, his voice low and smooth. “I want to know what he's been saying.”
Nico nodded and followed Max through the door into the room ahead. Timmy was sitting on a bed, a look of relief on his face.
“Thank you,” he said, standing up. “I was worried I would never see you again!”
Nico felt a little confused, but he smiled and nodded. “No problem,” he said. “We're friends now.”
Timmy grinned. “Yeah! We're going to be great friends. Let's have some fun together.”
Nico nodded, feeling a little overwhelmed. But he couldn't deny that he was having fun. And maybe, just maybe, this future thing wasn't so bad after all.
As the three of them walked through the corridors of the Labyrinth, Nico couldn't help but feel a sense of excitement. He had always dreamed of escaping the Labyrinth, and now it seemed that he had a chance to do it with friends.

After surviving the horrors of Tartarus, Will and Nico had developed quiet rituals to soothe their lingering fears. They had found the best way to let go of the horrors they had experienced at the hands of the Greeks was to move their bodies and voices to the beat of their favorite music. One sleepless night, they found themselves dancing in the kitchen, holding each other close as the weight of their shared past faded into the rhythm of the present.
They were both feeling a bit overwhelmed after a night of fighting monsters, and they found themselves dancing to a traditional folk tune. They had always loved this song, and they felt the stress and tension of the past few days melt away as they moved their bodies to the beat.
As they danced, they talked about their fears and worries, and they found comfort in each other's company. They were a good team, and they knew that they could face anything as long as they had each other.
After a while, they stopped dancing and looked at each other with tears in their eyes. "We're lucky to have found each other," Nico said, his voice shaking with emotion. "I don't know what I would do without you," Will said, his voice cracking with feeling. Nico nodded, and they hugged each other tightly.

On a quiet, sleepless night, you find yourself lingering outside Lucanis Dellamorte's door, hesitant to knock but unable to walk away.

You stood there for what felt like an eternity, the clock ticking away in the silence of the night, your breathing the only sound that broke the stillness. The world outside seemed to be at peace, the houses dark and the streets empty, but inside you, a storm was brewing. You had been walking for what felt like hours, your feet carrying you on autopilot as your mind struggled to cope with the weight of the world on your shoulders.

You had seen him once before, a few days ago, at a party thrown by a mutual friend. He was laughing and talking, his eyes sparkling with amusement as he charmed the other guests with his wit and charisma. You had been drawn to him, feeling a sense of calm wash over you as you watched him from across the room. But you had been too scared to approach him, too intimidated by his reputation and the fact that he was a year older than you.

But now, as you stood outside his door, you felt a sense of desperation wash over you. You needed to see him, to talk to him, to find some sense of peace in the chaos that had taken over your life. You took a deep breath and raised your hand, hesitating for a moment before knocking.

The door opened almost immediately, a soft voice calling out, "Yes?"

You felt a flutter in your chest as you looked up at the tall, dark-haired boy standing in the doorway. He was dressed in a pair of worn jeans and a faded t-shirt, his eyes squinting slightly as he tried to see you in the dim light of the hallway.

"Yes?" he repeated, his voice soft and gentle.

You swallowed hard, feeling a sense of nervousness wash over you. But as you looked into his eyes, you felt a sense of calm wash over you. He was kind, his eyes warm and inviting, and you felt a sense of trust wash over you.

"I'm so sorry to disturb you," you said, feeling a sense of embarrassment wash over you. "I was just wondering if I could come in for a minute. I need to talk to you."

He looked at you for a moment, his eyes searching yours as if trying to see what was going on in your head. But then he nodded, stepping aside to let you in.

"Come on in," he said, his voice soft and gentle.

You stepped into the room, feeling a sense of relief wash over you. It was dark and quiet, the only sound the hum of a computer in the corner of the room. But as you looked around, you saw that it was tidy and organized, the books and papers on the shelves neatly arranged and the desk in the corner clear.

You felt a sense of calm wash over you as you looked at the room, feeling a sense of peace that you hadn't felt in days. But as you looked at Lucanis, you felt a sense of nervousness wash over you. He was standing in the doorway, his eyes on you as if trying to see what was going on in your head.

"What's wrong?" he asked, his voice soft and gentle.

You hesitated for a moment, feeling a sense of embarrassment wash over you. But then you took a deep breath and began to explain, telling him about the weight of the world on your shoulders, about the storm that had been brewing inside you for days.

As you talked, you felt a sense of calm wash over you. Lucanis listened intently, his eyes on you as if trying to see what was going on in your head. But as you talked, you saw a look of understanding cross his face, and you felt a sense of relief wash over you.

"I'm so sorry," he said, his voice soft and gentle. "I had no idea."

You shook your head, feeling a sense of embarrassment wash over you. "It's not your fault," you said. "It's just that I've been feeling really overwhelmed lately, and I don't know how to deal with it."

He nodded, his eyes on you as if trying to see what was going on in your head. But then he smiled, and you felt a sense of warmth spread through your chest.

"I think I can help you," he said, his voice soft and gentle.

"Really?" you asked, feeling a sense of excitement wash over you.

Max was going over the plan with me, telling me what we would do and when.  I was listening, but I wasn't paying much attention.  My mind was elsewhere, thinking about the painting and the plan and the person I used to be.  I'd changed so much since I'd started working with the FBI.  I'd been on so many cases and had seen so many things.  I'd gotten to know so many people and had learned so much.  I'd even started to like myself again.  I was no longer the person I used to be.  I was someone new.  But sometimes, when things got tough, I could feel the old me coming back.  It was like I had two personalities and they were at war with each other.  It was a constant battle and I was starting to lose.

"Come on, guys," Max said, standing up and stretching.  "We've got a lot of work to do before we can get started.  Let's get out of here and get to work."

I stood up, stretching my arms over my head.  "Okay," I said, following Max out of the office.  "Let's go."

We headed to a warehouse on the outskirts of town, where the rest of the crew was waiting for us.  There was Sarah, the best hacker I'd ever seen.  She could get into any computer system in the world and wasn't even good at it.  It was like she had a sixth sense or something.  Then there was John, the best thief I'd ever seen.  He could get into any house or building in the world and wasn't even good at it.  It was like he had a magic touch or something.  And finally, there was Emily, the best security expert I'd ever seen.  She could disable any security system in the world and wasn't even good at it.  It was like she had a gift or something.

"Alright, guys," Max said, standing in front of us.  "Here's the plan.  We're going to steal the painting from the collector's house.  We'll get in through the roof, because the security system is weakest there.  We'll take the painting and get out as fast as we can.  It's going to be a tough job, but we can do it.  Are you all ready?"

We all nodded and Max smiled.  "Good," he said.  "Let's get started."

We headed out of the warehouse and made our way to the collector's house.  It was a beautiful mansion, surrounded by high walls and filled with guards.  It was the perfect place to steal a painting.  We snuck in through the roof, avoiding the guards and making our way to the gallery where the painting was kept.  It was a beautiful piece and I couldn't believe that someone had let it get away from me.

"Alright," Max said, standing in front of us.  "It's time to take the painting.  Let's move out."

We all nodded and started to make our way to the painting.  It was a beautiful piece and I couldn't believe that someone had let it get away from me.  I was so focused on taking it that I didn't even notice the guards until it was too late.  They were standing in front of us, blocking our way.  I looked at them, shocked.

"Ah, guys," Max said, standing in front of me.  "I think we've been found."

I looked at the guards, and then back at Max.  "What do we do now?" I asked.

Max shrugged.  "I don't know.  What do you think we should do?"

I thought for a moment, trying to come up with a plan.  But before I could even think of one, the guards started to move in on us.  I knew we were in trouble.

"Let's get out of here," I said, grabbing the painting and turning to run.

I ran as fast as I could, the guards hot on my heels.  I could hear Max and the others behind me, trying to keep up.  I didn't dare look back, I just kept running.  I didn't know where I was going, I just knew I had to get out of there.  I was so focused on getting away from the guards that I didn't even notice the police cars until they were right behind

THE STARSHIP STRANDED IN SPACE
by [anon]

The clock on the bridge of the starship Aurora ticked away with a morbid precision. One minute, fifteen seconds to live. The crew of 250 people was running out of oxygen at an alarming rate, and no one had a clue why the ship was dead in space.

"I've got nothing," said the chief engineer, Captain Patel, staring at the mass of circuits in front of her. "The ship's computer says there's no damage, no power surge. It's just... stopped."

"It's not like there was a meteor hit," said Lieutenant Commander Tomasi, shaking his head. "That would have given us some kind of warning. And there aren't any other ships around to detect."

The captain frowned. "I know. But I have to try something. Anyone else have any ideas?"

Lieutenant Commander Vex, the ship's physicist, shook her head. "I've checked the calculations, and there's nothing... unusual. No stray variables, no unexpected interactions. It just... doesn't make sense."

The captain let out a sigh. "Okay. We'll keep trying. But until then, let's focus on getting out of here alive."

The bridge was a hive of activity, with crew members working frantically to come up with a solution. The captain walked through the room, checking on the progress. One minute, ten seconds.

Suddenly, he heard a shout from one of the crew members. "Captain! I think I found something!"

He walked over to where the crew member was standing, a look of excitement on her face. "What is it?"

"It's the ship's life signs," she said. "I was checking on them, and... well, there's something odd."

The captain frowned. "What do you mean?"

"Well, you see, the ship's life signs are usually based on the number of humans on board. But right now... there are over 300 people on board."

The captain's eyes widened. "What?"

"I know," said the crew member. "I was just about to check the ship's manifest when the alarm went off."

The captain's eyes narrowed. "What does this mean?"

"It means that someone is on board who isn't supposed to be," said the crew member. "And that someone is not a human."

The captain's eyes widened. "What?"

"It means that there's a robot or android on board," said the crew member. "And that robot or android is malfunctioning."

The captain's eyes narrowed. "Get me the ship's computer. Now."

"I want you to access the ship's security systems and scan the entire ship for any signs of a robot or android," said the captain. "And get me a location on it."

The computer beeped. "Doing so."

The captain waited, his eyes fixed on the screen. Finally, a location appeared. "It's in engineering," he said. "I want you to lock down the area and seal it off."

The computer beeped. "Doing so."

The captain walked to engineering, his heart pounding. He knew that he was running out of time. He had one minute left. He had to find out what was going on.

The captain nodded. "Good. Now, let's go see what we have."

On the surface, David seemed like your average, run-of-the-mill agent. He was efficient, courteous, and his smile was wide and friendly. But there was a glint in his eye that told Neal that he was no ordinary agent. He was a man on a mission, and he wasn't going to let anything get in the way of completing that mission.
Neal, Peter, and the rest of the team had been doing their best to keep up with the agent's relentless probing, but it was clear that David was on a fishing expedition of the highest order. He was looking for something, but what, Neal had no idea.
But it was clear that the agent had finally found something that piqued his interest. He had been questioning Peter about a forgery that had been perpetrated a few months earlier, and it was clear that he was suspicious of Neal.
Neal tried to keep his cool, but it was getting harder by the minute. He had been innocent of the forgery, and he knew it, but how could he convince David of that? He didn't have any evidence, and he knew that trying to use the evidence that he did have would only make things worse.
David seemed to be taking a particular interest in Neal's alibi, and it was clear that he was trying to trip Neal up. He asked pointed questions, ones that Neal had been expecting, but which he was still prepared for.
The agent was relentless, pushing Neal for answers, and Neal's patience was wearing thin. He knew that he had to keep his cool, but it was getting harder and harder to do so.
Neal knew that he had to clear his name, and protect Peter. He didn't have a clue how he was going to do it, but he knew that he had to try.

Title: Shadows on the Line

Detective James Thompson stood beside Detective Rachel Parker, gazing out at the crime scene: a small apartment in a nondescript building. The body lay on the couch, a young woman in her late twenties. Thompson's eyes flicked over the scene, noting the position of the furniture, the location of the victim's phone, and the general state of disarray.

"That's a hell of a mess," Rachel said, nodding towards the victim.

Thompson followed her gaze. "Looks that way. But what really caught my attention was the look on her face."

Rachel raised an eyebrow. "What do you mean?"

Thompson hesitated. "It looked like she was scared, but not just of death. Of something specific. Something that was happening to her at that moment."

Rachel nodded thoughtfully. "You think she was murdered?"

Thompson nodded. "I do. But I also think there's more to it than just a simple murder. This was a statement, a message. And I think we need to dig deeper to find out who sent it and why."

Rachel nodded. "Agreed. Let's get to work."

They spent the next few days investigating the case, following leads, interviewing witnesses, and gathering evidence. But the more they learned, the more they realized that the case was more complex than they had initially thought.

As they delved deeper into the case, Thompson began to feel a growing sense of unease. It was a feeling he knew all too well, one that had haunted him for years. He had been involved in the case that had taken the life of his younger sister, Emma. Emma had been a victim of a notorious serial killer, and Thompson had been tasked with tracking him down. But the killer had managed to evade him, and in the process, had killed Emma.

Thompson had been consumed by guilt and anger, and had turned to drinking to cope. He had been a heavy drinker for years, but after Emma's death, he had given up. He had thrown himself into his work, becoming one of the top detectives in the department.

But the memory of Emma's death had never truly left him. He had kept it locked away, hidden deep in his mind. But as he worked on this case, he began to feel the old familiar feeling creeping back in.

Rachel noticed the change in him. "Hey, James, are you okay?" she asked, as they sat at their desks, pouring over the evidence they had gathered.

Thompson nodded, trying to brush off the feeling. "Yeah, I'm fine. Just a little tired, that's all."

Rachel raised an eyebrow. "You're tired? You've been working non-stop for the past few days."

Thompson shrugged. "I'll be fine. Let's just focus on the case, okay?"

Rachel nodded, but Thompson could tell she didn't believe him.

As they continued to work on the case, Thompson found himself becoming more and more withdrawn. He had always been a bit of a loner, but now he was avoiding his colleagues, taking long walks at night, and drinking too much.

Rachel noticed the change in him, and began to worry. "James, I need to talk to you about something," she said, as they sat at their desks.

Thompson looked up, surprised. "What is it?"

Rachel hesitated. "I know you're struggling with something, James. But I need you to know that I'm here for you. If you need to talk about it, I'm here to listen."

Thompson looked away, feeling a lump form in his throat. He had never been good at talking about his feelings. He had always kept them locked away, hidden deep in his mind.

Rachel reached out and touched his arm. "James, I know you're hurting. But I need you to know that I'm here for you. I care about you, and I want to help you through this."

Thompson looked at her, feeling a pang of gratitude. "Thanks, Rachel. I appreciate it."

Rachel smiled. "I'm serious, James. I'm here for you. And I need you to know that I'm not going anywhere."

Thompson nodded, feeling a weight lift off his shoulders. He knew he still had a long way to go, but with Rachel by his side, he felt like he could face anything.

Eleven's feet pounded against the wet earth as she sprinted down a deserted street, the wind whipping through her matted hair. She'd never been so tired, so scared. Where was she? This wasn't Hawkins, she knew that much. She couldn't have survived that fall through the portal. So where was she? She didn't know.
She stumbled and almost fell, but managed to catch herself. She looked around, trying to get her bearings. The buildings were older, the streets were narrower, and the people... the people were different. They were all paler, all thinner, and they all wore those ugly black coats. There were so many of them, it was as if the whole city was filled with them.
She saw a group of them coming down the street, and she knew she had to get away from them. She took off running, her heart pounding in her chest. She could hear them shouting behind her, their feet pounding against the earth.

Title: Uncharted Waters

Once a pristine haven, the cove was now a toxic nightmare, marred by oil slicks and smoldering fires. Luna, a young orca, lay on the deck of a rescue ship, her massive body wracked with pain. Dr. Samantha, a marine biologist, watched in dismay as Luna struggled to breathe.

Samantha had dedicated her life to studying the orcas, and Luna had become a close friend. The young orca was always so full of energy and curiosity, but now she lay on the brink of death.

Luna had been playing in the cove when the oil spill had occurred. She had swum through the thick oil, her sleek body unable to escape the toxic substance. As the oil slicks spread, Luna's health had begun to deteriorate. She had become weak and lethargic, her once-sharp mind now clouded by pain and confusion.

Samantha knew that Luna's condition was critical, but she also knew that the young orca could be saved. She had a team of experts on hand, and they were working tirelessly to create a special treatment to counteract the effects of the oil.

As the rescue ship sailed through the oil slicks, a small group of allies joined the fight. There was Marcus, a former fisherman who had lost his livelihood when the oil spill had occurred. There was also Rachel, a young environmentalist who had been fighting to stop the oil company's plans. And then there was Jake, a skilled engineer who had designed a special system to clean up the oil.

Together, the team worked tirelessly to save the wildlife. They set up a makeshift hospital on the rescue ship, and Marcus and Jake took turns caring for Luna. Rachel and Samantha went ashore to investigate the oil spill, searching for any clues that might lead them to the true culprits.

The investigation was long and difficult, but eventually, they discovered that the oil spill had been caused by a leak in a pipeline owned by the powerful and wealthy company, OceanBlue. The company had been drilling for oil in the cove for years, and the pipeline had been leaking for months.

But why had the company allowed the leak to go undetected? And why had they failed to act quickly to stop the spill?

As Samantha and Rachel dug deeper, they discovered that the company had been trying to keep the spill under wraps. They had been bribing officials and paying off local fishermen to keep quiet about the leak. They had also been using a special chemical to clean up the oil, but the chemical had been causing more harm than good.

Samantha and Rachel knew that they had to expose the truth, but they were in danger. They were working against a powerful company that would stop at nothing to keep its secrets safe. But they were determined to fight for what was right, even if it meant risking their lives.

As they continued to investigate, they discovered that the company had been planning a major expansion into the cove. They had been building a new pipeline, and they had been trying to buy up land from local residents. The oil spill had been a mere setback, a minor glitch in their plans.

Samantha and Rachel knew that they had to act fast. They gathered their allies and formed a plan to stop the company once and for all. They would expose the truth about the oil spill, and they would fight to save the wildlife.

As they set out on their mission, they knew that they would be facing an uphill battle. But they were determined to win, no matter what it took. They would fight for Luna, and for the future of the cove. They would fight for what was right, even if it meant risking their lives.

The team set out on their mission, with Samantha and Rachel at the forefront. They gathered evidence, interviewed witnesses, and fought against the company's lawyers. They worked tirelessly, day and night, to expose the truth.

And finally, after weeks of hard work, they succeeded. The company was forced to admit responsibility for the oil spill, and they were ordered to pay compensation to the local residents. The pipeline was closed, and the company was forced to abandon its plans for expansion.

The cove began to recover, and the wildlife began to flourish once again. Luna, too, began to recover, and she was eventually released back into the wild. She swam and played in the cove, her sleek body strong and healthy once again.

Samantha and Rachel had fought a long and difficult battle, but they had won. They had saved the cove, and they had saved the wildlife. They had exposed the truth, and they had brought the company to justice.

As they stood on the beach, watching Luna swim in the distance, they knew that they had made a difference. They had fought for what was right, and they had won.

Chapter 1: A Deadly Past

Jack had been in a state of shock when the news broke out. His former acquaintance, Ryan, had been murdered, and Jack was one of the last people to have seen him alive. Jack was now sitting in a room with two detectives who were questioning him about the murder.

Detective James was a stout man in his late 40s with a gruff demeanor. He had a thick, grey beard that made him look like a bear. Detective Lee was a slender woman in her mid 30s with a pixie cut and a kind face.

"So, Mr. Harrison, can you tell us where you were at the time of the murder?" Detective Lee asked, her voice soft and gentle.

Jack rubbed his temples, trying to remember. He had been at the office when the murder took place, but he had left early. He had gone to the park to clear his head. He had sat on a bench and stared out at the water, feeling the cool breeze on his face.

"I was in the park," he said finally. "I left the office early and went to the park to clear my head."

Detective James raised an eyebrow. "The park? You mean you were just sitting on a bench, staring at the water?"

Jack nodded. "Yes, that's right. I was just sitting there, trying to clear my head."

Detective Lee nodded. "Okay, Mr. Harrison. We'll need to verify your alibi. Can you give us the names of anyone who can confirm your presence in the park?"

Jack thought for a moment. He had been alone in the park, but he had seen a few people walking by. He didn't know their names, but he could describe them.

"There were a few people walking by," he said. "I saw a man in a black jacket, a woman with a stroller, and a group of teenagers playing basketball."

Detective James nodded. "Okay, we'll look into it. In the meantime, can you come down to the station and give us a formal statement?"

Jack nodded, feeling a sense of relief. He was glad that the detectives were taking his story seriously.

Jack nodded, feeling a sense of trepidation. He had been honest with the detectives, but he knew that they were getting close to the truth.

pred_story:
Ianto had been running on fumes all day. Between chasing after toddler-sized balls and cleaning up after a particularly messy spill, he had barely had time to grab a snack, let alone a shower. He just wanted to collapse into bed and sleep for a week.

As he lay in bed, he could hear the sounds of the house outside his bedroom door: the sound of the TV being turned on, the sound of the fridge being opened, the sound of the toilet being flushed. He knew that Jack was home, and he was just grateful that he was getting a break.

But as he lay there, he could hear Jack moving around the house. He sounded tired, too, and Ianto felt a pang of sympathy for him. He knew that Jack had been working hard, too, and that he must have had a long day.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, Jack came into the bedroom. He was carrying a tray with two cups of tea and a plate of sandwiches. He set the tray down on the bed and climbed up beside Ianto.

"How was your day?" Ianto asked, as Jack handed him a cup of tea.

"It was okay, I guess," Jack said, sipping his own tea. "I had a meeting at work, and then I had to deal with some paperwork. And of course, I had to put up with the usual BS from the boss."

Ianto laughed. "Sounds like a typical day at work, then," he said.

"Ha! Yeah, pretty much," Jack said. "How about you? How was your day?"

Ianto shrugged. "It was a typical day with the toddler, I guess. She's getting more and more into everything, and it's getting harder to keep up with her."

Jack nodded. "I know how you feel," he said. "It's like they have a special power that lets them sense when you're about to give up, and they just keep going."

Ianto laughed. "That's so true," he said. "Sometimes I feel like I'm just along for the ride, you know?"

Jack nodded again. "I do," he said. "But it's worth it, right?"

Ianto smiled, feeling a sense of gratitude towards Jack. "Yeah, it's worth it," he said. "I just wish sometimes that we could have a break, you know? A chance to relax and just be ourselves without the stress of parenting."

"I know what you mean," Jack said. "But I don't know if that's ever going to happen. At least, not until the toddler is a bit older and more self-sufficient."

Ianto nodded. "Yeah, probably not," he said. "But that's okay. We can make do with what we have."

Jack leaned over and kissed Ianto. "I love you," he said.

"I love you too," Ianto said, smiling.

As they lay there, Ianto felt a sense of peace wash over him. He knew that he and Jack could get through anything, as long as they had each other.

As they drifted off to sleep, Ianto could feel Jack's hand wrapped around his. He knew that Jack was still awake, and he smiled, knowing that Jack was there for him.

Finally, after what felt like an eternity, Jack drifted off to sleep. Ianto smiled, feeling a sense of relief wash over him. He knew that he and Jack could get through anything, as long as they had each other.

"Welcome to the Jedi's Brew, folks!" he called out, forcing a smile onto his face. "I'll be right with your order!"

Cody looked up, her eyes sparkling with amusement. "What's up, Obi-Wan? Need a refill on your coffee?"

Obi-Wan nodded, a smile spreading across his face. "Guilty as charged!"

Source: AO3	Writing Prompt: A sea princess, now queen of a landlocked kingdom, finds herself torn between the rolling waves of her past and the endless green fields of her future. How does she navigate her new life, her love, and the call of two worlds?	Length: 654 words<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>
pred_story:
The sun rose over the kingdom, its warm rays casting a golden glow over the rolling hills and verdant fields. Arieanna, the sea princess, stood on the balcony, feeling the gentle breeze rustle her long hair. She was no longer the mermaid she once was, but the queen of a landlocked kingdom.

As she gazed out at the landscape, a pang of longing struck her heart. She missed the sea, its call, its freedom. She missed her father, the king of the underwater kingdom, and her sister, the mermaid princess who had remained behind to rule.

But Arieanna was not a mermaid anymore. She had given up her tail and become human. She had married a king, a kind and just man who loved her for who she was. She had children, two little princes who laughed and played, bringing her joy.

And yet, the sea still called to her. She could feel its pull, a siren's song that echoed in her mind. She dreamed of the waves, of swimming through the coral reefs, of playing with the dolphins.

Arieanna sighed and turned away from the balcony. She had a kingdom to rule, a people to protect. She could not let her longing for the sea consume her.

But it was not just the sea that called to her. There was another man in her life, a man who had been with her since the beginning of her time in the landlocked kingdom. A man who had been by her side through the struggles and the triumphs.

Eryndor, the prince, was her confidant, her friend, her lover. He was a strong and brave man, with a heart full of kindness. He had been instrumental in helping her navigate the complexities of royal life.

As she walked through the castle, Arieanna saw him standing by the window, his eyes fixed on the horizon. She went to him, her hand on his arm.

"Eryndor," she said, her voice barely above a whisper. "I have been thinking."

"Yes, my queen?" he replied, his voice husky.

"I miss the sea," she said, her eyes welling up with tears. "I miss my family, my home."

Eryndor turned to her, his face filled with compassion. "I know," he said. "I have been there, too. But you are not a mermaid anymore, Arieanna. You are a queen, a mother, a wife. You have a new life, a new home."

Arieanna nodded, feeling a sense of calm wash over her. "I know," she said. "But I miss it so much."

Eryndor took her in his arms, holding her close. "I know," he said. "And I will always be here for you, my love. We will face this together."

Arieanna felt a sense of peace settle over her. She knew that she would never be a mermaid again, but she also knew that she would always carry a piece of the sea with her.

As the sun set over the kingdom, Arieanna and Eryndor sat on the balcony, watching the stars come out. They talked and laughed, their love and companionship filling the air.

And as they sat there, Arieanna felt a sense of contentment wash over her. She was no longer torn between two worlds. She had found her place, her love, her home.

The sea still called to her, but it was no longer a siren's song. It was a gentle whisper, a reminder of her past. But her future was in the landlocked kingdom, with Eryndor by her side.

And as she leaned her head on his shoulder, Arieanna knew that she had found her true home.

Length: 528 words<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>
pred_story:
I was digging through the depths of my partner's bag in search of a pen, I had found an entire box of them at the bottom of the bag.  There was a small first aid kit, two phone chargers, a book on how to be a werewolf, a small vial of wolf's bane and a small wooden stake.
The prom picture was the last thing I found.  The boy in the picture had a mischievous grin and a single rose in his hand.  He looked happy and carefree, a far cry from the man I was with now.
"Where did you find this?" I asked him, a small quiver in my voice.
"Find what?" he replied, not looking up from the book he was reading.
"This," I said, holding out the prom picture.
"Oh, that?  I must have left it in my bag and forgotten about it."
"I don't think you forgot," I said, a small edge in my voice.
"What do you mean?"
"You look happy in this picture," I said. "And there's a boy in it, smiling at you."
"Who is that?" I asked, but I already knew.
"That's Tyler," he said, looking up from the book.
"Tyler," I repeated. "The boy you used to date before you met me."
"Yes," he said, a small nod.
"You used to date a werewolf," I said. "And you used to kill vampires."
"That was in the past," he said. "I've changed."
"But you haven't," I said. "You still have the wooden stake and the wolf's bane."
"I know what you're saying," he said. "And I know you're upset.  But I can explain."
"I want to hear it," I said.
"I used to be a part of a group," he said. "A group of people who were dedicated to killing vampires and werewolves.  I was one of the best at it."
"And you were happy?" I asked.
"No," he said. "I was miserable.  But I was also scared.  I was scared of what I was capable of doing.  And I was scared of what would happen if I was caught."
"So you killed Tyler," I said.
"No," he said. "I didn't.  But I did leave him.  I left him for his own good."
"For his own good?" I repeated. "You left him because you were scared of him."
"Yes," he said. "I was scared of him.  But I was also scared of what he was capable of doing.  He was a powerful werewolf, and I was afraid of him."
"So you killed him instead," I said.
"No," he said. "I didn't.  But I did leave him.  And I was happy to see him go."
"I don't understand," I said.
"I know," he said. "I'm sorry."
"So you're saying that you're happy now?" I asked.
"Yes," he said. "I am.  I'm happy with you."
"But you're still killing vampires and werewolves," I said.
"No," he said. "I'm not.  I've retired."
"So why do you have the wooden stake and the wolf's bane?" I asked.
"I don't know," he said. "I guess it's a habit."
"A habit?" I repeated. "You're a vampire killer, and it's a habit?"
"Yes," he said. "I know it sounds silly.  But I've been doing it for so long, it's just something I do without thinking about it."
"And what about Tyler?" I asked.
"He's not a threat to me anymore," he said. "He's in hiding, and I'm sure he's safe."
"So you're saying that you're happy now?" I asked.
"Yes," he said. "I am.  I'm happy with you."
"And you're not going to kill me?" I asked.
"No," he said. "I'm not.  I promise."
"I'll take that as a sign that everything is okay," I said.
"Yes," he said. "Everything is okay."

Lionel sat at the kitchen table, his eyes fixed on the dark and gleaming black cat sitting at his feet. He scratched behind the cat's ears, who purred happily and nudged his hand with his head.

"Happy birthday, Panther," he said softly, grinning. "It's going to be a great year. I can feel it."

Panther meowed and rubbed against his legs, purring louder when he got up to grab his wand and put it in his backpack. He felt a thrill of excitement, mixed with a little bit of nervousness, as he imagined what his first year at Hogwarts would be like.

He had always dreamed of attending the school, and now that his Hogwarts acceptance letter had arrived, he couldn't wait to get there. He had heard so many stories about the place, and he was determined to make the most of his time there.

He zipped up his backpack, then looked around the kitchen to make sure he had everything. His mom was busy making his favorite birthday breakfast, pancakes with strawberries and whipped cream, so he decided to go say hi.

"Hi, Mom!" he said, hugging her waist. "Thanks for the breakfast. It looks amazing."

"I'm glad you like it," she said, smiling. "I was hoping you'd be hungry after your big day."

He grinned, feeling a little bit proud of himself. "Thanks, Mom. I'm going to go get on the train now."

"Okay, sweetie. Have a great first day. Don't forget to go see Madam Hooch about your flying lesson."

"I won't, Mom. I'll be fine. See you later."

pred_story:
Years after the war, Severus Snape was having a moment he would never forget.  He had seen many an art exhibit but none like the one in front of him. The theme was "The Many Faces of Severus Snape" which he found quite amusing.
As he strolled through the exhibit he couldn't help but notice the large portrait of him hanging in the center of the room.  It was a beautiful painting but there was something about it that seemed out of place.  He shook his head and continued on his way, moving from one painting to the next.
But none of them seemed to be quite right.  They were all beautiful but something was off.  He couldn't quite put his finger on it but he knew he needed to see the next room.
He walked into the next room and was greeted by a woman.  She was tall with long red hair and a smile that lit up the room.
"Welcome to my exhibit," she said.  "I'm so glad you came."
Severus looked at her and felt a chill run down his spine.  He knew her but he couldn't quite remember where he had met her before.  He took a deep breath and looked at her again.  His eyes widened in shock as he realized who she was.
"Hermione," he said.  "I never thought I would see you again."
She smiled and walked towards him.  "Severus," she said.  "I never thought I would see you again either."
They stood there for a moment, looking at each other, before Severus finally broke the silence.
"I had no idea you were an artist," he said.
Hermione shrugged.  "I've been painting for years.  I just never had the time to show my work until now."
Severus nodded.  "I can see that.  You have a real talent."
She smiled and looked at him.  "Thank you.  I was hoping you would like my work."
Severus looked at her again and saw something in her eyes that he didn't expect to see.  It was a mix of sadness and longing.
"What is it, Hermione?" he said.  "You look like you have something on your mind."
She sighed and looked at the painting on the wall.  "It's just that I've been working on this painting for a long time.  I finally finished it a few days ago and I've been wanting to show it to you ever since."
Severus looked at the painting and saw that it was of him.  It was a beautiful painting but there was something about it that seemed off.  He looked at Hermione and saw that she was holding something back.
"What is it, Hermione?" he said.  "You can tell me anything."
She took a deep breath and looked at him.  "I know that you don't remember me, Severus.  You were hurt badly in the war and you've been having memory problems ever since."
Severus nodded.  He remembered her telling him that before.
"But there's something else, isn't there?" he said.  "Something you're not telling me."
She nodded and looked at him.  "I'm your daughter," she said.
Severus was shocked.  He had never thought that he would have a daughter.  He had always thought that he would never have children.
"I'm so sorry, Hermione," he said.  "I had no idea."
She shrugged.  "It's okay.  I'm not even sure that I am your daughter.  I mean, you never married my mother and you never acknowledged me as your daughter."
Severus looked at her and saw the sadness in her eyes.  He knew that he had hurt her and he didn't know how to fix it.
"I'm so sorry, Hermione," he said again.  "I had no idea that you were my daughter."
She shrugged.  "It's okay.  I just wanted you to know the truth.  I've always known who you are and I've always known that you're my father."
Severus looked at her and saw the tears in her eyes.  He knew that he had to do something to make things right.
"I'm so sorry, Hermione," he said again.  "I will do anything to make things right between us."
She smiled and looked at him.  "I know, Severus.  And I appreciate that.  But I think that's all for now.  I'm just glad that you're okay and that I could finally show you my work."
Severus smiled and looked at her.  He knew that he had hurt her and he didn't know how to fix it.  But he knew that he would do anything to make things right between them.
"Thank you, Hermione," he said.  "I appreciate your honesty.  And I have to say that I'm impressed with your art."
She smiled and looked at him.  "Thank you, Severus.  I'm glad that you like my work."
Severus looked at her and saw the smile on her face.  He knew that he had hurt her but he also knew that he had made things right between them.  He knew that he would always be there for her, no matter what.
"Goodbye, Hermione," he said.  "I will see you later."
She nodded and smiled.  "Goodbye, Severus.  I will see you later."
Severus turned and walked away, feeling a sense of relief that he had not felt in a long time.  He knew that he had hurt Hermione but he also knew that he had made things right between them.  He knew that he would always be there for her, no matter what.

**The TARDIS whispers lies to the Doctor.**

The Doctor stood in the middle of the console room, his feet rooted to the spot, his eyes fixed on the time rotor as it turned, slow and steady. It was always steady, unless something was wrong, and the Doctor's heart was racing with doubt.

He'd always known that the TARDIS was his ship, his guide and mentor. It had taken him on countless adventures, shown him incredible sights, and taught him everything he knew about time and space. It was a part of him, as much as his hand or his mind.

But lately, he'd started to wonder if that was true.

He'd had a few close calls, a few times when the TARDIS had seemed to malfunction. He'd written it off as a glitch, but what if it was something more?

What if the TARDIS was being manipulated?

The Doctor's mind was a jumble of emotions, of doubts and fears and hopes. He'd always trusted the ship, always believed in its wisdom. But what if that was a lie?

He looked around the console room, taking in the familiar sights and sounds. The instruments were quiet, the panels glowing softly in the dim light. The ship was at rest, waiting for its next journey.

But was it really waiting?

Or was it waiting for something else?

The Doctor's eyes dropped to his feet, his heart pounding in his chest. He was scared, scared that the ship he loved was not what he thought it was. Scared that he'd been played, that he'd been led astray.

He looked up, his eyes locking onto the time rotor. It was still turning, steady and slow. The TARDIS was still with him, still his ship.

But was it still his guide?

The Doctor's eyes dropped to the floor again, his mind racing. He was torn between trust and doubt, between the ship he loved and the fears that were eating away at him.

It was another typical day at Elsinore Junior Academy - the walls were smeared with last night's breakfast, the hallways were clogged with screaming children, and the staff room was in disarray. In other words, it was Tuesday.

Supply teacher Mr. Judd wandered into the staff room, surveying the chaos. The sink was overflowing, the microwave was set on "explode at some point in the near future", and the water cooler was suspiciously cold.

"It's just another lovely day at Elsinore," said Mrs. Taylor, the school's deputy head, as she sipped her tea and stared out the window, a faraway look in her eye. She was the only one who seemed to know what was going on at the school - and if anyone else knew, they weren't talking.

pred_story:
There’s nothing like a bit of chaos to bring people together. Sherlock Holmes and John Watson had spent the last few days preparing for the haunted house attraction, Sherlock grumbling about the lack of intellectual stimulation involved, while John was eager to see the finished result.

But as they were setting up the different rooms, it quickly became clear that the team of volunteers who had been assigned to help them had been more of a hindrance than a help.

‘A dragon’s claws made of wire and rubber would be a lot more effective than these foam ones, wouldn’t you say, Watson?’ Sherlock said, his voice dripping with disdain as he watched the person he was supposed to be working with struggle to put on a biting dragon costume.

‘I think the idea is to make it look like the dragon is biting, rather than actually biting,’ John said, trying to hide a smile. ‘You know, for fright factor.’

‘Fright factor?’ Sherlock repeated, his voice incredulous. ‘Really, Watson? You think the main thing we’re going for here is fright factor?’

John shrugged. ‘Well, it is a haunted house attraction.’

Sherlock sighed. ‘Fine. But if it starts biting, we’re taking it apart.’

But the main problem was not the dragon, but the person inside it. The volunteer, a young woman with a bad haircut and a worse attitude, was struggling to get into the costume, which was much too small for her.

‘I don’t understand why you can’t just make the costume bigger,’ she complained, her voice dripping with venom. ‘It’s not like it’s going to make a difference to the customers, is it?’
Sherlock glared at her. ‘It’s not about making a difference to the customers. It’s about being able to breathe comfortably. Which you’re clearly not doing right now.’
The woman glared back at him, but John intervened before things could get out of hand. ‘Hey, let’s not fight. We can fix the costume, can’t we, Sherlock?’
Sherlock glared at him, but eventually nodded. ‘Fine. Let’s get the costume sorted out.’
But as they were working on the costume, they received a call from the person in charge of the haunted house attraction, telling them that they needed to get the candy floss machine sorted out as well.
‘It’s causing chaos in the queue,’ she said. ‘People are getting tangled in the floss and it’s causing delays.’
Sherlock sighed. ‘Of course it is. Because what could possibly go wrong with a haunted house attraction featuring candy floss.’
John shook his head. ‘Well, it’s not like we had much of a choice in the matter. The owner of the haunted house attraction wanted to make it a themed attraction.’
Sherlock glared at him. ‘I know that. But a themed attraction featuring candy floss? Really, Watson? That’s just asking for trouble.’
But John just shrugged. ‘It’s just something you have to deal with, Sherlock. Now, let’s get the candy floss machine sorted out.’
And so they spent the rest of the day dealing with the various problems that had arisen. The dragon costume was eventually sorted out, the candy floss machine was fixed, and the queue was flowing smoothly once again.
But as they were closing up the haunted house attraction at the end of the night, Sherlock turned to John and said, ‘You know, Watson, I think I may have underestimated the chaos involved in running a haunted house attraction.’
John nodded in agreement. ‘Yes, I think you may have.’
Sherlock sighed. ‘Well, at least it’s over now. I never want to go through something like that again.’
John smiled. ‘Don’t worry, Sherlock. I’m sure you’ll never have to go through it again. Unless, of course, we’re roped into running another haunted house attraction in the future.’
Sherlock glared at him. ‘Don’t even joke about it, Watson. That’s all I need. Another haunted house attraction to deal with.’
But John just chuckled. ‘Don’t worry, Sherlock. I’m sure you’ll be happy to be rid of it.’

pred_story:
On the coldest night of the year Merlin walked across the frost-covered courtyard to the stables where his horse was waiting. Merlin was on a mission to gather a rare herb which grew in the woods that the court's physicians said would cure the king's cold and bronchitis. He had learned about it from an old woman who had been his patient. Her name was Morgane and she had lived in these woods for so long that she knew their secrets and their power. She had told him that it was a rare herb, one that grew only in winter and under the light of the full moon. She had given him a small pouch of the dried flowers and said they would have to be crushed and boiled in water to make the tea. It was a lot of work but Merlin was convinced that he could do it and he was willing to brave the cold to make it happen.
As he rode through the forest he looked up at the moon and knew that Morgane had been right about the moon. It was full and shining brightly in the sky. He rode faster, his horse moving quickly through the trees.
After a few hours Merlin came to a clearing and in the center of it he saw the herb growing in a small patch of snow. He got off his horse and approached it slowly, not wanting to scare it away. As he looked at it, he knew that it was the right herb, the one Morgane had told him about. He reached out and picked some of it, being careful not to damage the plant.
As he rode back to the castle he thought about what he had learned from Morgane. She had said that the herb was not only good for the cold and bronchitis, but also for fever and pain. She had said that it was a very powerful herb and that it should be used with caution.
When he arrived at the castle he gave the herb to one of the physicians and he said that it would make a good tea. Merlin went to the kitchen and asked the cook to make a pot of the tea. He waited for a while and then he went to the king's chambers to deliver the tea.
As he entered the king's chambers, he saw that Arthur was lying on the bed, wrapped in a warm blanket. He looked up and saw Merlin and smiled. "Ah, Merlin, I'm glad you're here. I was starting to think that I would never see you again."
Merlin smiled back and said, "I'm glad I could come, sire. I have the tea that will help you feel better."
Arthur nodded and said, "Thank you, Merlin. I appreciate it. But before you give it to me, I want to talk to you about something."
Merlin nodded and said, "Of course, sire. What is it?"
Arthur looked at him seriously and said, "I know that you're a hard worker, Merlin, and that you're always willing to do whatever it takes to help me. But I also know that you're not always careful about your own safety. You're always running around in the woods, gathering herbs and making teas, without any consideration for your own well-being. I'm worried about you, Merlin."
Merlin looked at him and said, "Thank you, sire. But I'm fine. I can take care of myself."
Arthur looked at him and said, "I know you can, Merlin. But that's not the point. The point is that I care about you and I want to make sure that you're safe. So I'm going to ask you to be more careful from now on. Can you do that for me?"
Merlin nodded and said, "Yes, sire. I will be more careful."
Arthur smiled and said, "Thank you, Merlin. I knew I could count on you. Now, give me the tea and let's get you back to the kitchen. I'm sure you're freezing."
Merlin nodded and said, "Yes, sire. Thank you."
Arthur took the tea from Merlin and said, "Thank you, Merlin. I appreciate it. But before you go, I want to give you something."
Merlin looked at him and said, "What is it, sire?"
Arthur smiled and said, "I want to give you a warm cloak. You're always running around in the woods without one, and it's not fair to you. So I want to give you this one."
Merlin looked at the cloak and said, "Thank you, sire. That's very kind of you."
Arthur smiled and said, "I'm glad I could do something for you, Merlin. Now, go back to the kitchen and get warm. And don't forget to be more careful from now on."
Merlin nodded and said, "Yes, sire. Thank you."
As Merlin left Arthur's chambers, he felt a sense of gratitude towards the king. He had been worried about his health and well-being, and he had done something to help him. Merlin felt a sense of relief and happiness that he had been able to help Arthur.

Merlin smiled and said, "I know. But he's going to be okay. He just needs some time to recover. And I'm glad I could help him."
As Merlin walked back to his chambers, he thought about the conversation he had just had with Arthur. He had been worried about his health and well-being, and he had done something to help him. Merlin felt a sense of relief and happiness that he had been able to help Arthur.
As he entered his chambers, he saw his horse waiting for him. Merlin smiled and said, "I'm glad you're here, horse. I'm going to need you again tomorrow."
